captions.text:
The earth completes a full rotation once per
day, and hence the moon passes overhead pretty

much once daily. So then why are there two
high and low tides every day?

Simple: the moon's gravitational attraction
is stronger the closer you are to it. So the

close side of the earth gets pulled away from
the middle, which in turn gets pulled away

from the far side. As the earth rotates, these
so-called "tidal forces" cause water on the

surface to slosh around as "high tides" twice
per day - when the moon is directly over your
head and directly below your feet.

So why is gravity weaker at a greater distance?
Well, imagine you're spraying a stream of

water at a sheep [flamingo]. If the sheep's
more distant, less of the water hits it than

when it's close, so there's less force pushing
it away. Gravity behaves the same way, except
it's attractive.

And there are tidal forces from the sun as
well: they're weaker than the lunar ones,

but when the sun and moon line up [on the
same or opposite sides of the earth] the tides
pack an extra punch.

It's not just water that sloshes, though - tidal
forces cause the earth's crust to bulge as

well - we just don't notice because we get
lifted along with it. And tidal forces from

the earth cause the moon to bulge, too! All
this bulging and sloshing dissipates some

of the earth's rotational energy, causing
it to gradually slow its rotation. Eventually,

the earth will spin slowly enough that the
same side of the earth will always face the

moon - just as the same side of the moon already
always faces the earth! This means that in

the distant future, a day and a lunar month
will each have the same length: about 50 of
our current earth days.

What's more, if the moon were to get too close
to us, tidal forces from the earth would be

stronger than the gravity holding the moon
together, so rocks on the moon's surface would

literally start flying off into space, and
the moon would disintegrate. This would also

happen if the earth were to get too close
to the sun - and if you decided to fly into

a black hole, it's what would actually do
you in: your spaceship would get ripped apart

from tip to tail by tidal forces. Now that's
bad tidings.

complications.

Laplace first modeled the theoretical sloshing, but it took quite a bit of 
math and data collection to finish the job to the predictive capabilities 
we have today, in which the tidal forces resonating through the water is 
approximated using spectral analysis.

comments.author: ssjEasterBunny

comments.text:
it's all relative, the "near" (to the moon) side just gets pulled more and 
as you go further it's pulled less and less (towards the center of the moon 
that is, each bit is also pulled by a more or less equal force towards the 
center of the earth).

if the earth drops away beneath then that just means you're looking at it 
from the point of view of sea level on the far side (though really it won't 
be pulled it's close to equilibrium), the actual vector quantities of the 
forces are in a certain sense equivalent regardless of the reference frame.
comments.author: foobargorch

comments.text:
One way to wrap your brain around this is to ponder the idea of how planets 
orbit the sun at different periods base on their distance from the 
sun.Earth takes a year. Jupiter takes over a decade to complete  an obit 
and for objects like Pluto it takes over a century to complete one orbit. 
The sea bed on the far side of Earth is slightly closer to the sun than the 
ocean above it. The ocean basically takes slightly longer to orbit the sun 
so it lags a little behind creating that tidal bulge.I hope this helps.

comments.author: Doge

comments.text:
TL;DR: Centrifugal force wants parts of rotating object to move outwards, 
gravity from object holds those parts back, if object disintegrates, the 
gravity pull gets weaker, so the formerly rotating object will fall apart 
and its fragments will drift into all directions.

Long, tedious and still incomplete and oversimplified explaination:

The most important point here is inertia.
This works regardless of whether it's plantes being ripped apart by a 
strong gravitational field or atoms being ripped apart by a black hole, but 
in the case of the latter, there's other forces at work.
You got an object, which is held together by gravity, which is basically 
the force of the entirety of its mass(technically, it isn't, but let's keep 
it at that for simplicity's sake) and the centrifugal force(which again, 
technically isn't a force, but let's keep it at that, for simplicity's 
sake) pulling the atoms of the object outwards due to its rotation.
The whole thing is way more complicated, but let's keep it at these 
two(basically wrong) principles. Mass gets pulled outwards by centrifugal 
force and mass gets pulled inwards by the rest of the object's mass.

If there is a strong gravitational pull from the outside, the shape of the 
object will start to bend. Basically, the combination of inertia and 
gravity will cause the atoms to be pulled away from the center even 
further, but they will be pulled back in, once the rotation of the object 
draws them away from the source of gravity. That's basically, what the tide 
does. As the whole object gets pulled by the outside source, there will 
also be a part, where the gravity pull from the outside source will be the 
weakest. The place, which is the farthest away from the source. As the rest 
of the object gets pulled stronger, this part will also bulge outside by 
virtue of not being pulled towards the gravity source as strong. As the 
centrifugal force is only dependant on the distance to the center of the 
rotating object, the part with the lowest gravitational pull will bulge 
further away from the source, than the part slightly closer to it.

Now, what happens, when the object disintegrates, is, that the gravity, 
which upheld its shape isn't strong enough anymore to hold it together. As 
pieces drift apart, there will be less and less mass situated close to the 
far side of the object. That part of the object will have less and less 
gravitational force pulling it towards the rest of the object, as those 
parts drift away and there is no single object to speak of anymore. This 
will cause the whole object to fall apart, as the fragments will move 
outwads due to their inertia(or centrifugal force, which is a horrible word 
and shouldn't be used, when talking about proper physics, but I went ahead 
and did it anyway)

This whole thing only works for rotating objects(if they didn't rotate, 
they would collide way too fast for any disintegration of the objects to 
matter anyway) and whether fragments are thrown away from the source of 
gravity or everything gets sucked in depends entirely on how fast the 
rotation was and how strong the gravitational pull is.
comments.author: naphackDT

comments.author: Antonio Tunjic

comments.text:
+Antonio Tunjic stop being so vague. To clarify things: We get affected, 
sure, but a tiny tiny tiny tiny amount. the formula that gives the force of 
gravity is F=G*(m1*m2)/r^2 where G is a constant and let's say m1 is the 
mass of the moon and m2 is your mass. Since your mass is so so so so much 
smaller than the moon's mass, the gravitational force ( F ) becomes 
stupendously small and doesn't actually affect you at all. Get science'd!
comments.author: Akis Kyraleos

same strength everywhere in your body. As we spin with the earth, this 
strength changes over time, but the difference is really small (compared to 
the gravity of the earth) so I doubt that there are any effects from this 
change.

comments.text:
+William Albert Okay :)
Don't get me wrong, I've never tried to say there's scientific facts (or 
any fact for that matter) that can't be proven wrong, it's just that Steven 
Crum threw off well established theories without having evidence for their 
falseness.
I've just thought of something though: Isn't science itself somewhat of a 
religion? Because we have to believe that real knowledge does exist before 
we go after it; before we do science. And then, another question pops up: 
Aren't the most common religions just cheap ways of dealing with the idea 
that there is real knowledge? Because everyone of them states supposedly 
absolute truth without any evidence. So, on one hand they say, yes, there 
is real knowledge and on the other hand they explain the world not based on 
experience but on the words of their god, who usually doesn't have any 
solid evidence for the truth of his words.
Don't answer to that. I just had to write it down, so I don't forget about 
it x)
comments.author: KalaMiDeviL

comments.text:
+KalaMiDeviL
Those words are used interchangeably in common usage even though they 
shouldn't.In science the hypothesis is the idea that's based on early 
observation and experimentation. Theory is the fully mature idea based on 
"rock solid"experiments and observation. A good explanation of this can be 
found in Niles Eldredge's "The Monkey Business". Even the best Theories 
regarded as "fact" have fallen by the wayside or have been modified.This is 
why science is NOT a religion.
comments.author: William Albert

comments.text: Wait, why can't I read Steven Crum's comments anymore?
comments.author: KalaMiDeviL

comments.text:
+William Albert Oh, I'm sorry x)
I thought, "theory" was the english word for what would actually be a 
hypothesis…
So, a hypothesis is a idea based on experience but without evidence 
supported by  pre-knowledge, right?
comments.author: KalaMiDeviL

comments.text:
+KalaMiDeviL
Yes it is a theory. All ideas in science are ether hypothesis (weak) or 
theories(strong). This theory happens to be a very strong one just like the 
Copernican Theory or the Evolutionary Theory. Still they are all 
falsifiable.  There are no facts in science, only ideas. All of which could 
be proven wrong and replaced with newer hypothesis and theories.The heat 
attraction thing LOL is not a valid theory, of coarse, and you are right to 
dismiss it out of hand.There is an experiment using two dense metal balls 
suspended by string close together with a mirror on one of the strings 
reflecting a laser beam.The gravitation pull was measured using this 
technique and it did verify the standard equation we were taught in physics 
class.  Come to think of it,the Newtonian equations which were great for 
predicting planetary motion broke down in describing the shifting of 
Venus's perihelion.Einstein's equations solved this mystery and superseded 
Newton.
comments.author: William Albert

to each other, because placing them somewhere means that there is friction 
that has to be overcome and gravtiation is one of the weakest forces out

strong enough to pull stuff around by the way but I don't know everything. 
So, obviously, tides are caused by the gravitational force of the moon and 
the sun. The water won't ever leave earth though, since it's closest to it 
and gravitational pull, as we know, depends not only on the mass but also 
on the distance between the objects pulled together.Still, the water tends 
to gather on earth's area that's closest to the moon and also to the sun, 
although the sun's influence is only about half as big as the moon's 
because it's so far away. That's also, why we have spring tide and dead 
tide. Depending on the positioning of the sun and the moon, their 
gravitational pulls add up or cancel each other out. As for that confusing 
tide on earth's area furthest from the moon, that is caused by the shifting 
of the terrestrial orbit through the moon's attraction. It's not just the 
moon orbiting around earth and earth orbiting around the sun, since for 
every force, there's an anti force. However, because force depends on the 
mass of an object, the same force won't have the same effect on every 
object. So, the sun's acceleration because of earth's gravitational pull is 
ridiculously small and earth's acceleration because the moon's 
gravitational pull is relatively small. We can't neglect it, though, at 
least in the case of the moon. That's where centrifugal force comes into 
play. Because there's a slight movement of earth towards the moon, after 
the moon has circled around earth once, earth has moved in a small circle 
as well. The water (and the earth) furthest away from the centre of said 
circle receives the strongest pull. Compare it to a fast spinning 
carrousel. If you're on that carrousel and you stick your hand out, you can 
feel it being pulled away strongly and you can feel your blood rushing into 
its fingertips. That's the common answer for the bilateral tides on earth.
comments.author: KalaMiDeviL

comments.text:
+KalaMiDeviL Not so much, it is the earth being pulled more towards the 
moon (because it is closer, so the gravitational pull has more grip on it) 
so the water appears to bulge.
comments.author: Doge

comments.text: +DrAugurk Hint: centrifugal force
comments.author: KalaMiDeviL

comments.text:
Wouldn't the water slowly have been sucked to the side of the moon? I get 
that the gravity of the moon is less on the "Dark side" of the earth but it 
would get sucked to the side of the moon eventually right? Please enlighten 
me :)
comments.author: Doge

comments.text:
+ScottPlays______ No, it only bulges the earth crust a little bit. Using a 
little bit of logic, we can know that high tide in one place means low tide 
somewhere else; it is taking water from elsewhere.
+lbliss It is more noticeable on the sea because the sea is liquid and 
liquid moves easily.
comments.author: La-di da

comments.text:
+Ibliss
Because water, being a liquid, will actually lower on regions not being 
afected as much, migrating to the area nearest to the Moon and thus 
increasing the height difference. As you phrased, "it takes water from 
areas farther away from the moon", but it also does bulge the Earth's 
crust. The latter not being affected as much for being solid.
comments.author: Leonardo Scur

comments.text:
Well then why is the effect on the sea much more noticeable than on the 
land?
comments.author: Ibliss
